fields.description:
As the administrator of one account I can delete an access key owned by the administrator of another account by simply providing its ID:

{code}
#!/bin/sh -xe

euare-accountcreate -I $AWS_ACCESS_KEY -S $AWS_SECRET_KEY -a one
euare-accountcreate -I $AWS_ACCESS_KEY -S $AWS_SECRET_KEY -a two

euare-useraddkey --as-account one -u admin > one-creds
euare-useraddkey --as-account two -u admin > two-creds
ONE_AKID=$(sed -n 1p one-creds)
ONE_SKEY=$(sed -n 2p one-creds)
TWO_AKID=$(sed -n 1p two-creds)
TWO_SKEY=$(sed -n 2p two-creds)
unset AWS_ACCESS_KEY
unset AWS_SECRET_KEY

euare-usergetattributes  -I $ONE_AKID -S $ONE_SKEY
euare-accountaliaslist   -I $ONE_AKID -S $ONE_SKEY
euare-userlistkeys       -I $ONE_AKID -S $ONE_SKEY
euare-usergetattributes  -I $TWO_AKID -S $TWO_SKEY
euare-accountaliaslist   -I $TWO_AKID -S $TWO_SKEY
euare-userlistkeys       -I $TWO_AKID -S $TWO_SKEY

euare-userdelkey --debug -I $ONE_AKID -S $ONE_SKEY -k $TWO_AKID  # should fail
euare-userlistkeys       -I $TWO_AKID -S $TWO_SKEY || echo DOSed
{code}

Example output:
{code}

+ euare-accountcreate -I AKIPTCS2MQYD4PIMTF5P -S D1gGswVS6pwu0xIjqRzZqsbxtxmt61kxbaXzuoZE -a one
one	001581182070
+ euare-accountcreate -I AKIPTCS2MQYD4PIMTF5P -S D1gGswVS6pwu0xIjqRzZqsbxtxmt61kxbaXzuoZE -a two
two	699093237975
+ euare-useraddkey --as-account one -u admin
+ euare-useraddkey --as-account two -u admin
++ sed -n 1p one-creds
+ ONE_AKID=AKIJDCGUXY0J7W4F2DWU
++ sed -n 2p one-creds
+ ONE_SKEY=WnOOSRWbvyhq8yIOdZfaqsKUOSZDbY5pnHEVFso5
++ sed -n 1p two-creds
+ TWO_AKID=AKIYCWGA15AAVILQA1PU
++ sed -n 2p two-creds
+ TWO_SKEY=Z3RnbxdSsZpWrXRKkendIjmCkJgtqza4neVD3pfz
+ unset AWS_ACCESS_KEY
+ unset AWS_SECRET_KEY
+ euare-usergetattributes -I AKIJDCGUXY0J7W4F2DWU -S WnOOSRWbvyhq8yIOdZfaqsKUOSZDbY5pnHEVFso5
arn:aws:iam::001581182070:user/admin
AIDADGTXJKQXXFTY946VE

fields.summary: Accounts can delete each others' access keys given the keys' IDs

comments.body: [~sjones], is checking that the key belongs to the user in DatabaseUserProxy the right way to handle it? Cloud admins and the account admin should be able to delete keys (and other resources) belonging to other users.
[~rusvika], that functionality will still be available, they will just have do delete via the owning user (which they should already be doing)
[~mmunn1], the fix should go into a security branch, not maintenance branch.
[~sjones], is it possible to estimate in which Euca version this issue was introduced or can we assume it was "always" there?
[~rusvika], I had a look at the 3.1 branch and it appears to have the same issue but I did not test any version.

[~sjones], thank you! I think in the ESA I will just then say "Eucalyptus 4.1.1 and earlier". If we are reasonably sure that this issue is relatively old, the exact version when it was introduced is not super important if users are not likely to run a prior version.
[~sjones] If I understand this correctly what we want is to only get/remove/modify/update keys or certificates, if the user key matches the associated key of the resource being acted on?

[~mmunn1], I think you are saying that we should only act on keys or certificates that are owned by the user being acted on, in which case yes that is correct. For example, if you try to access a certificate (e.g. CertificateEntity#getUser) that is not owned by the user (i.e. DatabaseUserProxy#delegate) then we should fail (possibly with AuthException#NO_SUCH_CERTIFICATE, we should check the AWS/IAM error code)
[~sjones] Yes that is what I am thinking, thanks. I will look into how AWS handles the errors.

Code Review Request : EUCA-10882 Accounts can delete each others' access keys given the keys' IDs

branch : dev-mmunn1-EUCA-10882

diff :  git show --color 8a5536575b4f0ba9e3ab74fb91973c45a1e00a6e

Summary: Account admins can delete each other's keys and certs

Solution: In DatabaseUserProxy check to make sure the delegate is the owner of the key/cert by checking the returned list for getKeys() and getcerts().
If the list is empty the delegate is not the owner, throw appropriate error
If the list is not empty compare list values against the delegate value, if no match the delegate is not the owner,throw appropriate error.
The errors thrown are: AuthException.NO_SUCH_CERTIFICATE or AuthException.NO_SUCH_KEY, this matches AWS behavior.

Passed full regression test http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch/2891/
Unit test : described in comments, 
I tested euare-userdelcert,euare-usermodcert,euare-userdelkey,euare-usermodkey and now only the owner of the Key/Cert
can remove or modify the resources.

Checking "this.isSystemAdmin" is not correct here as this is not a permission check but rather an ownership check. Ideally we would not load the data twice, from a security perspective it would be better to check the ownership on the items that are actually returned rather than loading in an alternative way to check ownership.

For testing it will be important to verify that administrative functionality is not broken (i.e. testing the same commands but using the --as-account option)

[~sjones] I am unclear on what you mean by "Ideally we would not load the data twice, from a security perspective it would be better to check the ownership on the items that are actually returned rather than loading in an alternative way to check ownership."?

The fix adds methods checkKeyOwner/checkCertOwner that load the data in order to check ownership. These methods are invoked, the loaded data is checked and then the calling method separately loads the data that is actually returned to the caller.

[~sjones] I modified the fix as per you suggestions:

branch : dev-mmunn1-EUCA-10882
diff : git show --color e93beeb198ab18e29abb4db82594efac2babb8e1

Tested with remove/mod keys/certs with and without --as-account and -u options and it is working correctly.
Ran full regression test http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Maint-4.1/44/

Fix Verified.

Accounts cannot delete others access keys they know of. Tested using the test script. Also verified that using --as-account also has the fix and cannot delete other's access keys given the IDs

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.1.2
Release     : 0.0.23225.100.20150625git8189ec3.el6
